passages.text: August 28, 2025 04:07 AM GMT
Urban Outfitters Inc. (URBN.O) Price Target
Strengthens our thesis Impact to our thesis
Modest upside Financial results versus consensus
Modest revision higher Direction of next 12-month consensus EPS
Source: Company data, Morgan Stanley Research

2Q EPS beat on sales upside & BTL items. 3Q & FY EPS guidance set \~in- line & above, respectively, & appear beat- able. Remain Overweight rated given 1) positive EPS revision potential, 2) relative tariff insulation, & 3) high relative sales growth & rare margin expansion oppty TY. Raise PT to \(\) 84\$
2Q EPS came in above expectations, but with operational performance more \~in- line (i.e., below- the- line benefits).
Initial 3Q guidance & updated FY guidance strike us as beat- able.
AMC stock pressure likely due to bullish pre- print positioning & high inventory levels; we suspect stock recovers as market digests objectively strong print.
Stay Overweight on 1) positive EPS revisions, 2) relative tariff insulation, & 3) rare sales growth/OM expansion oppty - but potentially mostly appreciated.
Raise PT to \(\) 84\(on higher base year forecast.

View (+): We remain Overweight rated. 2Q made for another solid print in a string of many, with the keythetets of our positive view on display: 1) 2Q outperformance & updated guidance underscoring URBN as one of few stocks with a clear line of sight into solid T topline growth & profitability expansion TY - even including tariffs, 2) 2Q trends lending further credibility to the positive rate of change story at UO - impressively while the Anthro/FP banners remain strong, & 3) the FY GM guidance raise exemplifying the business' relative tariff resilience. Further, we leave with incremental confidence in URBN's positive fiscal '26e EPS revision potential, even on raised FY guidance (more below). That said, we admit much of this may be already appreciated considering the stock's \(+35\%\) YTD run, meaning the risk/reward is less attractive than when we initially upgraded the stock in January (more here). Our revised \(\) 84\$ price target offers \~15% upside to AMC levels.
2Q (=/+): URBN delivered 11c of 2Q26 EPS upside on 1) sales growth/comp outperformance (+11%/5% vs. Street \(+9\% /4\%\) , 2) slight GM upside (37.6% vs. Street

For analyst certification and other important disclosures, refer to the Disclosure Section, located at the end of this report.

\(37.5\%)\) , 3) a more favorable tax rate ( \(\sim 2c\) benefit), 4) better interest income ( \(\sim 5c\) benefit), & 5) share repurchase support ( \(\sim 2c\) benefit). Put differently, operational performance was more \(\sim\) in- line vs. the headline EPS beat (\$174M EBIT vs. Street \$172M). This was a function of lesser topline upside flow- through in SG&A, which mgmt. attributed to intentional marketing investment - a dynamic that will continue into 3Q (more below). In our view, the primary blemish on the 2Q26 print was outsized \(+15\%\) inventory growth (vs. 3Q +HSD % sales growth guidance), which mgmt. somewhat quelled by 1) attributing levels to an intentional tariff- related pull- forward, & 2) reiterating its commitment to manage inventory growth more in- line with sales growth by the end of 3Q. Altogether, we view this as a solid print, reflective of broad- based comp momentum & seemingly strong &/or improving profitability trends across banners.

3Q (=/4): Mgmt. set 3Q profitability guidance a touch below the Street, but EPS \(\sim\) in- line ( \(\sim\) high- 8% EBIT margin & \(\sim\) \$1.20 EPS implied at the midpoint vs. Street 9.5% & \$1.18, respectively). This lower profitability outlook reflects mgmt.'s view 1) that 3Q GM could come in \(\sim\) flat y/y on tariff headwinds (vs. Street \(+20\) bps y/y), & 2) SG&A growth & subsequent y/y deleverage could be above Street expectations on intentionally higher marketing investment (possibly \(+10\%\) y/y vs. consensus \(+8\%\) y/y). That said, favorable BTL items (specifically lower tax rate & shares outstanding guidance) yield an \(\sim\) in- line implied EPS guide. We see room for possible 3Q26 EPS upside to guidance, as 1) 2Q's +LDD % sales growth performance could continue into 3Q (vs. mgmt. expectation for a deceleration to \(+HSD\%\) ), 2) projected tariff impacts potentially prove overly punitive (as they have for most in 2Q), 3) mgmt. has seemingly built in an SG&A buffer, & 4) 2Q26's below- the- line boosters may selectively recur. We subsequently model 9.4% 3Q26 OM & \$1.24 EPS. This is 1) above mgmt. guidance ( \(\sim 8.9\%\) & \(\sim\) \$1.20 implied, respectively) & 2) above prior (9.0% & \$1.12) on sales at the higher end of the guidance range (+9% y/y), & subsequently less SG&A de- leverage.

FY (+): Mgmt. guided implied '26e EPS above the Street ( \(\sim\) \$5.20 EPS implied vs. Street \$4.93). Similar to the dynamics at play in 2Q, this reflects a slightly above- consensus FY sales growth & GM outlook (+HSD % y/y & \(+100\) bps y/y vs. Street \(+7\%\) y/y & \(+80\) bps y/y, respectively), partially offset by higher- than- Street SG&A growth as mgmt. intentionally invests in marketing (+10% y/y implied vs. Street \(+8\%\) y/y). We see room for upside to even revised higher FY guidance for reasons similar to our 3Q view. More specifically, this updated FY outlook embeds 1) a -3 pts 2H growth deceleration from 1H's 11% levels, 2) potentially overly punitive 2H tariff impacts, & 3) room to trim SG&A, if necessary. Thus, we model \$5.33 FY EPS - +LSD % above \(\sim\) \$5.20 implied guidance on higher FY sales & GM assumptions (+10% y/y & 35.9% y/y guidance \(+9\%\) y/y & 35.8%). This is \(+HSD\%\) above our prior FY EPS forecast for the same reasons (i.e., improved sales & GM assumptions).

Stock Reaction (- ): URBn stock fell - 5% AMC - we think a function of 1) some cooling off on bullish pre- print positioning (as evidenced by URBN's pre- print 14x valuation well above 11x Specialty peer avg.), 2) some picking at the 2Q25 print (e.g., operationally more \(\sim\) in- line & elevated inventory growth), & 3) some potential skepticism around the 4Q GM improvement embedded in guidance. We suspect the stock recovers as market further digests what was an objectively strong print.

Model/PT: Our fiscal '26e forecast increases \(+8\%\) to \(55.33\) (vs. \(69.93\) prior), driven by 1) 2Q outperformance, & 2) higher 2H sales & GM expectations (see above). We then flow through this higher base year to our M- T operating forecast, though our assumptions remain largely unchanged (+MSD avg. topline growth & - LDD % avg. OM through fiscal '29e). Alongside consistent CF assumptions & an updated WACC, this yields an \(\) 84\(PT (vs.\) \ \(82\) prior). This implies 16x fiscal '26e P/E, above URBN's current 14x valuation, but below its 20x pre- Covid highs.

- UO sustains positive comp growth, & subsequently regains profitability.- Anthro & FP successfully maintain current sales momentum & record profitability.- FPM & Nuyly each become \$1B businesses, as mgmt. has suggested.
- UO momentum proves temporary, and/or Anthro/FP sales growth moderates- Anthro/FP are unable to sustain record profitability levels

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Equal-weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Not-Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12-18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In-Line (I): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Cautious (C): The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12-18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia -relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub-regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
